151228814.review:
[h1] NEKOPARA: Catnip for the Curious, and Well... More! [/h1]
Welcome to the whimsical world of NEKOPARA, where catgirls reign supreme, and the plot takes a backseat to, well, some purr-plexing assets! 🐾

If you're in it for the feline-friendly fun, this visual novel will have you questioning whether you're a true cat lover or simply an enthusiast of...round shapes. Yes, we're talking about the NEKOPARA characters' ample assets. The creators have clearly decided that the cats in this game got more than their fair share of milk because, seriously, those proportions are nothing short of awe-inspiring.

The catgirls themselves are a sight to behold, and not just because of their adorable ears and tails. NEKOPARA boldly goes where few cat-based stories have gone before, putting the 'ecchi' in 'meowchii.' The bouncy physics of certain anatomical features could easily rival a trampoline park – talk about defying the laws of gravity with a furry twist!

The narrative is like the catnip that keeps you coming back for more, weaving a tale of patisseries, sisterly love, and a generous helping of double entendres. But let's be honest, the real stars of the show are the characters'...umm, personalities. They're just so well-rounded!

So, if you're looking for a game that embraces the philosophy of "plot over plot," and you have a penchant for catgirls with, shall we say, impressive assets, then NEKOPARA might just be the purr-fect match for you. Get ready for a tail-twitching, head-turning adventure that's bound to leave you feline fine! 🐱✨

150133599.review:
Some negative experiences, you just have a speech lined up for. Because something wonderful or at least interesting was on the line, and you want to vent the loss of the baby with the bathwater.

But for Nekopara? This kinetic visual novel that has just taken Steam by storm?

It has been a while since I have met something that somehow manages to be so underwhelming and uninteresting and yet quite so disgusting. Such so, that I don't even feel much need to copy-paste most of the copious notes I've taken as to why this is one of the most noxious, revolting, dislikable pieces of trash I've ever entertained on my hard drive.

But let me share a few.

There are major incestuous themes or at least implications that go unpunished, even presented as wholesome or pleasant; the "catgirls" are *nothing* like cats - the things in this VN are way too friendly, loyal, and affectionate to have *anything whatsoever* to do with felines - and there is generally an atmosphere and worldbuilding core of abuse in glittery paint. Aside from the incest, or at least incest-coded interactions, these human girls with cat features are "owned", living as slaves, as living playthings, and it's played up as this wholesome thing. And the writers have the gall to try to push some BS that they're actually more cat than human, "because ears and tail." It's like an excuse for a right-wing political policy; so stupid and insufficient to allay the elephant in the room it's supposed to explain away, delivered so confidently and unapologetically it either forces you to go along with it or sickens you to your gut. Or both.

__

But okay, let's say you're kind of feeling in the mood for an "Arabamu" lewd setup and you think the Emancipation Proclamation was a mistake. Well, what's wrong with Nekopara then?

Plenty, frankly. The story is underwhelming and uninteresting, just a day-by-day with no evident stakes and it basically being anime people doing anime things until you get to lewd scenes. I'd be up for a slice-of-life, if it's interesting, but Nekopara isn't.

The characters themselves, which are supposed to be the meat of the experience, apparently, get redundant and annoying, really fast; their interactions and dialogue might be bearable, even sparsely likable, in a different sort of VN, but for a game wie're here for the lewds for and we know it? And one *THIS LONG*? They're just obnoxious and don't add anything interesting to the plot or social atmosphere.

Speaking of lewd? Perhaps the biggest outrage of all is that it's not even in here, by default. You have to pay the whole price of the VN again, just to see what is probably only two or three scenes that I bet I could easily look up on a seedy website if I wanted to. It's insulting. Yes, I dislike that the dialogue seems to be incest-coded, but if you're going to put that in a game you are expressly selling for its lewd content, at least have the stones to double down and put your lewd content in as part of the main, whole purchase, lock, stock, and barrel.

Oh, did I say game? Excuse me. This isn't even a game. It's a "kinetic visual novel". There's no option to interact with the story or characters in any way. This just plays in one direction, with the same outcome, each time. This is basically a porn video if you ever thought "gee, I sure wish these porn videos had *more* talking heads, had most of their action in subtitles, and that I had to regularly click to make it play instead of clicking the once and just watching" - oh, and where you have to buy the video, then buy it *again* to see the actual *porn* in it.

And for gosh sakes, even the worldbuilding isn't worth a dime. The aforementioned genetic excuse they pull out of their ass for the girls' being cats is just the tip of the iceberg. There are stupid rules about the arrest of these "cat" girls, a "family" of eight somehow surviving on a singular traditional candy shop...

For hell's sake, even though this takes place in a bakery, and the Kashou guy presents himself as being all qualified and set up as a proper baker, through and through, I am convinced he's a fraud. He calls a Sponge Cake batter a "dough".an eyebrow-raiser but forgivable.

But wrapping it up and saving it for later!? WRAPPING! UP! *SPONGE CAKE*! BATTER! and SAVING IT FOR LATER!? I am in an Advanced Baking course as I type this (just got back, a bit of a coincidence now that I think about it) and this is one thing we DO NOT DO WITH SPONGE CAKES!

___

If this were some obscure niche VN tucked in Steam's dark corners, maybe I wouldn't feel this angry. But the fact this is so popular that Steam expressly merchandises animated avatar images and other things about it, and its pics are all over the place for anything to do with lewd games or sci-fi cartoon girls to date? That is insulting. There are a hundred games that deserve stardom more than this - NSFW and SFW alike.

If you really want to spend ten - or depending on how desperate you are, twenty- dollars on a frustrating ghost of an experience when you could buy much better ones for five dollars or see a much longer one for free, go for it. Just don't say I didn't warn you.

148290244.review:
People who only watched the anime: aw, what a cute and wholesome story.
People who played the VNs: do they know?

[h1] Introduction [/h1]

Nekopara Vol. 1 is a slice-of-life visual novel, and it's the first of a series of four visual novels (excluding the prequels, Nekopara Extra and Nekopara Vol. 0). It even has an anime adaptation for those who want to check it out. Being a slice-of-life story, it isn't a plot driven story by any stretch of the imagination, but this means that the characters need to be likable at the very least. Lets see if there are any merits to this game.

[h1] Worldbuilding [/h1]

Surprisingly, the worldbuilding of this game is solid and consistent. The game is set in modern Japan, and has similar, if not the same, rules of the real world. The difference is that catgirls are a thing. As a side note, some people think catgirls belong to the category of furry, which is wrong. Catgirls belong to kemonomimi, which are human, save of the animal ears. The game describes very consistently the characteristics of catgirls, the rules to which they abide and their influence on human society. The only gripe I have with the worldbuilding is that those elements are described mostly through exposition dumps instead of dialogue that flows naturally with the story and the characters. Another thing I noticed is that the absence of catboys, because the game establishes that catgirls can get pregnant, but not through a human, so that means that catboys must exist, but they are never mentioned. Something to think about.

[h1] The plot (or lack thereof) [/h1]

The story is simple. It's about a pastry chef that wants to open and run his own bakery, in opposition to what his parents wanted, and a very peculiar kind of employees join him to work at said bakery. Then the story focuses on the relationship between the two star catgirls and his new owner. Overall, the writing is solid, but not stellar, but there is a plot hole at the end of the story in which a character says something that contradicts something they previously said, and that facilitated the drama that followed. The pacing was good and the tonal shifts were spot on. The dialogue is good overall, but... why dialogue during H-scenes is so cringy? I may never know.

[h1] The characters [/h1]

The characters of this game, save one, are static, and, in the context of a slice-of-life story, it isn't a bad thing. The thing that matters is that the characters are consistently characterized and need to have distinct personality traits. Note that the names of the catgirls are always of ingredients used regularly in bakery. There are in total six catgirls (plus one that is a side character), but the main subjects of this story in particular are Chocola and Vanilla. They are very endearing characters. Chocola is a catgirl who wear her emotions on her sleeve and it has a very upbeat personality. Vanilla is more subdued but her deadpan jokes and the way she conceals what she really feels is, like I said, endearing. Regarding the main character, Minaduki Kashou (he will become a very, very lucky guy), undergoes a small change, because he wanted to run his bakery on his own, showing his selfishness, but then he accepted the help of Chocola and Vanilla. Shigure, his younger sister, is a total brocon. I'll leave it at that. Overall, the characters, especially Chocola and Vanilla, are very likable characters, but Kashou can be a bit boring at times.

[h1] Presentation [/h1]

The art direction is in the middle of the pack. Not bad, but not excellent either. Character artstyle, though, is very good, whether be in event CGs or the animated models, and the animations are very well done, expressive and life-like, and the way the ears of the catgirls perked up or drooped based on their emotional state is a nice little detail, plus, it looks very cute. The voice acting is also very good, the music fits the tone and the situation nicely, and the H-scenes are also excellent, though I wished that the scenes were at 60 fps, because in every other situation, the game ran at the same framerate as the refresh rate of my monitor (165 fps in the case of my gaming laptop and 240 fps in the case of my gaming PC). The player can also change between Traditional Chinese, English and Japanese text on the fly. The game also gives the player the option to adjust jiggle physics. Nice. Push "P" to see the effects.

In conclusion:

[b] Pros: [/b]

-Soild worldbuilding, with small exceptions.
-Endearing and likable characters.
-Good presentation overall (including H-scenes)

[b] Cons: [/b]

-Some plot issues at the end of the story.
-Main character can be a bit boring.
-At 10 hours, is a bit too short for the price (base game and 18+ DLC).

So, all in all, the game has enough merits to earn my recommendation. If you expected good storytelling in this game, then you are looking in the wrong place. Slice-of-life stories don't need traditional storytelling, only cute and likable characters doing cute things (and some extremely lewd things in this case), and this game delivers on that regard. Also, the presentation is worthy of praise, but I strongly recommend to wait for a good discount on the base game and the 18+ DLC, so you can get more for your money.

When I played Vol. 0, I made the joke that I had many unanswered questions regarding the existence and status of catfolk in this world. I fully expected it to just be glossed over or handwaved, to be honest. Now I just feel like a fool.

Imagine my genuine surprise when the mental checklist of out-there, absurd worldbuilding requests I planned to joke about was slowly ticked off throughout the game. Things like the view of catfolk/human relationships, the rate of aging, catfolk's status in society, whether or not catfolk and people can reproduce, etc. Why would a cutesy eroge bother even mentioning any of this, I thought? Hence why my absurdist review would mark that as a faux complaint. But it's all there, and as subtly horrific as it should be. And I love that.

In all seriousness, it's very cute. The ero scenes are whatever, I'd honestly say not to bother spending the extra cash on em if you're on the fence about it. Ultimately, though, it's your call whether you want this as a hardcore eroge or a cutesy romance story. I can respect the fact that it caters to both crowds.

Hail fellow gamers, the name's Kiba Snowpaw, a devoted ice wolf from the frozen reaches of an ice world! Gaming for more than three decades now, with an anime and manga collection that can outshine any library's manga section, I'm here to give you my take on a game that's been sending chills down my icy fur. Also, let's clear something up first - I'm not a stranger to the "birds and bees", nor the "wolves and does", if you catch my drift. With plenty of action in the igloo (wink wink), this review, despite the game's nature, isn't written out of frustration or desperation. 😏❄️🐾

Nekopara has been on my radar for some time now. My experiences on Patreon, Kickstarter and Bandcamp, supporting indie developers' dreams with substantial investments, all funnel into my evaluation. This isn't just another notch on the bedpost; it's a passionate night with a new partner, a game that's opened up a new world of enjoyment.

Diving straight into the nitty-gritty, this game's an eroge, or an erotic game for the uninitiated. Yes, it does come with steamy scenes that might put the heat on my icy world, but that doesn't mean it lacks content elsewhere. As a hardcore gamer with a knack for an immersive storyline, let me tell you - Nekopara knows how to weave a tale.

You're in charge of a bakery and have the company of adorable anthropomorphic catgirls (referred to as Nekos) who, by the way, are wonderfully brought to life with exquisite animation. The game, with its captivating characters, pleasing music, and lively voice acting, does an excellent job of recreating the atmosphere of a bustling bakery. And, a little pro tip for my fellow eroge adventurers out there: there's a boob bounce slider that defies physics if you want it to. Just sayin'... 🎮🐱💕

Now, it's easy to get lost in the... ahem... physical aspects of Nekopara. But, let's not forget about the intriguing plot that pulls the heartstrings at the right moments. These Nekos aren't merely human-feline hybrids bred for amusement. They come with their own histories, dilemmas, and insecurities. The game's society deals with complex issues such as abandonment, compliance tests, and GPS tracking that add depth to this supposed erotic escapade. It's a unique amalgamation of dystopia, ethics, and human-feline relationships.

Given the darker undertones, Nekopara might make you question the reality of this seemingly utopian world. It's akin to a cute, fuzzy, and sexy version of Brave New World meets The Handmaid's Tale.

However, folks, let's remember that at the end of the day, it's a game, and a darned good one at that. I've navigated the plains of Azeroth, conquered the universe in Mass Effect, fought off the Covenant in Halo, and Nekopara stands proud in this illustrious company. Why? Because it does something different and pulls it off spectacularly.

There's a special place in my heart (and my Steam library) for games that offer something more than just mindless action or soulless erotica, and Nekopara is one of them. The art, story, and interaction all combine to make a game that's worthy of the hundreds, if not thousands, of hours you'll lose within its world. 🐾💗🎮

So, whether you're an eroge veteran like yours truly or a curious newcomer, Nekopara is worth your time. There are many worlds to conquer, quests to undertake, and catgirls to... ahem... meet, but remember: it's not about the destination, it's about the journey.

Stay frosty, gamers! Remember to always enjoy the game and embrace what makes it unique. This is Kiba Snowpaw, your furry friend from the ice world, signing off after another frostbitten gaming night. Until next time! 🐺❄️🎮

Nekopara Vol.1 stands as a testament to the creativity, craftsmanship, and passion of its developers. This game fire 10/10. Anyways here is a recipe on a lemon poppyseed cheesecake

1-1/2 cups graham cracker crumbs
3 tablespoons butter, melted
4 packages (8 ounces each) cream cheese, softened
1 cup sugar
2 tablespoons all-purpose flour
2-1/2 teaspoons vanilla extract
5 large eggs, room temperature, lightly beaten
1/2 cup heavy whipping cream
1/4 cup lemon juice
1 tablespoon grated lemon zest
1/3 cup poppy seeds

Preheat oven to 350°. In a small bowl, combine graham cracker crumbs and butter. Press onto the bottom and 1 in. up the sides of a greased 9-in. springform pan. Set aside.
In a large bowl, beat cream cheese, sugar, flour and vanilla until smooth. Add eggs, cream, lemon juice, zest and poppy seeds. Beat on low speed just until combined. Pour into prepared crust.
Place pan on a baking sheet. Bake until center is almost set, 55-60 minutes. Cool on a wire rack for 10 minutes. Carefully run a knife around edge of pan to loosen; cool 1 hour longer. Refrigerate overnight. Remove sides of pan. Refrigerate leftovers.

Oh my catnip, let me tell you about Nekopara, the anime that's guaranteed to make you purr with delight!

Now, if you're not already a fan of catgirls, then Nekopara may not be your cup of milk. But if you are, then get ready for a meow-velous time!

The show follows the story of Kashou Minaduki, a young man who opens a patisserie and hires a bunch of catgirls to work as his assistants. And when I say catgirls, I mean girls with ears and tails who can meow and purr and do all sorts of other cute cat things.

The animation is simply purr-fect, with beautiful backgrounds and character designs that will make your whiskers tingle. And the music is so catchy, you'll be meowing along in no time!

But let's talk about the real stars of the show - the catgirls themselves! There's Chocola and Vanilla, the main catgirls who have a sweet tooth and a love for their master that's almost as strong as their love for catnip. Then there's Azuki and Coconut, the two older sisters who are more serious and responsible, but still know how to have a good time. And let's not forget about the youngest catgirls, Maple and Cinnamon, who are just too cute for words.

The interactions between the catgirls and their master are hilarious and heartwarming, and the show has just the right amount of fan service to keep things spicy without being too... ahem, racy.

Overall, Nekopara is a delightful and charming anime that will leave you feline fine. So if you're a fan of catgirls, sweets, and cute things in general, then this is the purr-fect show for you!

129604087.review:
Ah, Nekopara, the so-very-famous Eroge with catgirls and "Overwhelmingly positive" reviews here on Steam and everywhere! Surprisingly the plot goes like this: Kashou runs away from home to open his own cafe and live his dream to become a baker, against his filthy rich family's will. But to his surprise, he is followed by two loyal catgirls of his household, who could not fathom living without him. This series is/was such a success that it spawned 5 games plus one OVA. Is it really all of that?

Let me confuse you for a moment and say "yes, it is". The UI is high quality, way above those cheap RenPy VNs you see around, though it uses the strange low-res (which is typical for japanese Eroge). The art is magnificent. It is richly voice acted. There is quite some character development in the whole series, even though the plot is simply about their daily lives.

The problem here are the heroines. They look, talk and act way too young. Yeah, they are cute, but in an innocent kind of way. This is an Eroge, so, c'mon. Moreover, this is not really a game, but a "kinetic novel". There are 0 choices. It is basically an anime (a hentai, if you have the R18 patch). There is one big feature that might end up being overlooked: you can have the subtitles in English AND Japanese. Quite handy if you're learning Kanji.

Achievements come from simply progressing the game. No Linux port, but worked fine on Proton (thanks Valve!). The cards from this game were once one of the most expensive on Steam but they have since chilled a bit and became more affordable.

Even though I am a raging nekophile [spoiler]someone who loves catgirls[/spoiler] I'm not recommending this one. Get this only if you're an absolute pervert. Which you might be. I'm not judging.

128694475.review:
"A cat is fine too..."

I want to immediatly state that i don't necesarily think NekoPara is bad or that i wouldn't recommend it to anybody, far from it. I definitely think NekoPara does everything it wants to do and does it well. Sadly it just didn't click with me at all and this review is a summary with some points as to why.

NekoPara always seemed like one of the big classic Visual Novels on Steam. Mainly because it released at a time when the Storefront didn't read like the titles of DVDs you would find in  Video rentals in a Red Light District and Visual Novels (especially H-Visual Novels) were rather scarce, so my curiousity was certainly piqued a little going into this after all these years.
What i got was an expected Harem-Romance Visual Novel with hilariously high Production for a really forgettable, rather tame Love Story between a very bland, generic MC and two biologically engineered Girl-Cat Hybrids.

The art is good, the music is cheery (although a little limited) and almost the entire cast got full Voice Acting. The Portraits have a suprising amount of Animation going on and feel very lively and expressive, it was quite the pleasant suprise.

As for that cast, Chocola and Vanilla at times can come of as a little intrusive and annoying unfortunately. Chocola more so as she never seems to dial it back. Repetition happens a LOT in the entire VN and i never felt so inclined to flatout skip dialogue in a Visual Novel before. The other catgirls barely have a presence in Vol. 1. Shigure, the little sister with the hots for her big Brother the MC, gave me the creeps.

I can deal with the silly world of Catgirls existing and essentially being second class citizens but if your leads can't carry the story it ultimately becomes very monotone and boring. It overall just felt like a dime a dozen Anime Plot you have seen, read and heard lots of times before.

Also since this is technically an 18+ Game, let's briefly talk about that. Cheesy sound effects, the two girls yelling the same lines for twenty to thirty minutes repeatedly and the heavy pixelation did nothing for me in the slightest. Either i am into way more frisky and kinkier stuff or i am too old to get excited about (no pun intended) Vanilla Intercourse. Regardless i think an Asking Price of around 8 Bucks for these 18+ Patches is way too high.

117907185.review:
Nekopara, a kinetic visual novel reputable for its NSFW DLC and memes relating to it, is a game that follows the main character Kashou taking in two major heroines -- Vanilla and Chocolate, both neko-girls -- and starting up a cafe against his father's wishes. The game is the typical rom-com type anime about a family involving numerous neko-girls, which comes with the well-known anime-esqe fanservice (young women with likable personalities).

Nekopara unfortunately does not shatter new ground to the genre and relies heavily on the "kawaii~"-ness of the main neko-girl heroines. The KVN has basic morals to its story such as [i]follow your dreams[/i] and [i]love your family[/i], but it does not feel that said morals were as fleshed out as they could of been. If you are looking for an "emotional" KVN or one that's lighthearted in its storytelling then Nekopara is fine; however, when compared to competition, it really shows its flaws.

In conclusion I would not recommend this game. There are better games out there that would better take up your time.

It is rare that a video game makes me cry, and Nekopara was honestly the last place on earth where I expected this would happen.
First off, I really enjoyed the cute graphics (sadly no ultra wide support), the dialogues are well thought out and the voice acting is overall very enjoyable (props to the person who voiced the fly!).
What really went under my skin tough was how Chocolat and Vanilla express their affection and loyalty towards their master time and time again. I was especially surprised how sensual and honestly the scene was conveyed where Chocolat confesses her feelings for her master. It didn't feel distasteful or weird, but rather invoked a feeling of self-reflection in me, and I realized that being almost in my 40s, I will probably continue to live miserably until I die alone and unloved, while tears started to run down my face.

Well played Nekopara, well played. You took me to places I didn't expect nor wanted to experience, for that alone you deserve a solid 10/10.

Good Evening, My Fellow Citizens:
This government, as promised, has maintained the closest surveillance of the Soviet military buildup
on the island of Cuba. Within the past week, unmistakable evidence has established the fact that a
series of offensive missile sites is now in preparation on that imprisoned island. The purpose of these
bases can be none other than to provide a nuclear strike capability against the Western Hemisphere. Upon receiving the first preliminary hard information of this nature last Tuesday morning at 9 a.m., I
directed that our surveillance be stepped up. And having now confirmed and completed our
evaluation of the evidence and our decision on a course of action, this government feels obliged to
report this new crisis to you in fullest detail.
The characteristics of these new missile sites indicate two distinct types of installations. Several of
them include medium range ballistic missiles, capable of carrying a nuclear warhead for a distance of
more than 1,000 nautical miles. Each of these missiles, in short, is capable of striking Washington,
D.C., the Panama Canal, Cape Canaveral, Mexico City, or any other city in the southeastern part of
the United States, in Central America or in the Caribbean area. 
Additional sites not yet completed appear to be designed for intermediate range ballistic missiles --
capable of traveling more than twice as far -- and thus capable of striking most of the major cities in
the Western Hemisphere, ranging as far north as Hudson Bay, Canada, and as far south as Lima, Peru.
In addition, jet bombers capable of carrying nuclear weapons are now being uncrated and assembled
in Cuba while the necessary air bases are being prepared.
This urgent transformation of Cuba into an important strategic base -- by the presence of these large,
long-range, and clearly offensive weapons of sudden mass destruction -- constitutes an explicit threat
to the peace and security of all Americas, in flagrant and deliberate defiance of the Rio Pact of 1947,
the traditions of this nation and hemisphere, the joint resolution of the 87th Congress, the Charter of
the United Nations, and my own public warnings to the Soviets on September 4 and 13. This action
also contradicts the repeated assurances of Soviet spokesmen, both publicly and privately delivered,
that the arms buildup in Cuba would retain its original defensive character, and that the Soviet Union
had no need or desire to station strategic missiles on the territory of any other nation. ...
But this secret, swift and extraordinary buildup of communist missiles -- in an area well known to
have a special and historical relationship to the United States and the nations of the Western
Hemisphere, in violation of Soviet assurances, and in defiance of American and hemispheric policy --
the sudden, clandestine decision to station strategic weapons for first time outside of Soviet soil -- is a
deliberately provocative and unjustified change in the status quo which cannot be accepted by this
country, if our courage and our commitments are ever to be trusted again by either friend or foe. ...
Acting, therefore, in the defense of our own security and of the entire Western Hemisphere, and under
the authority entrusted to me by the Constitution as endorsed by the resolution of the Congress, I
have directed that the following initial steps be taken immediately:
First: To halt this offensive buildup, a strict quarantine on all offensive military equipment
under shipment to Cuba is being initiated. All ships of any kind bound for Cuba from whatever nation
and port will, if found to contain cargoes of offensive weapons, be turned back. This quarantine will
be extended, if needed, to other types of cargo and carriers. We are not at this time, however, denying
the necessities of life as the Soviets attempted to do in their Berlin blockade of 1948.
 Second: I have directed the continued and increased close surveillance of Cuba and its
military buildup. The foreign ministers of the OAS, in their communique of October 6, rejected
secrecy on such matters in this hemisphere. Should these offensive military preparations continue,
thus increasing the threat to the hemisphere, further action will be justified. I have directed the Armed
Forces to prepare for any eventualities; and I trust that in the interest of both the Cuban people and
the Soviet technicians at the sites, the hazards to all concerned of continuing the threat will be
recognized.
Third: It shall be the policy of this nation to regard any nuclear missile launched from Cuba
against any nation in the Western Hemisphere as an attack on the United States, requiring a full
retaliatory response upon the Soviet Union.
Fourth: As a necessary military precaution, I have reinforced our base at Guantanamo,
evacuated today the dependents of our personnel there, and ordered additional military units to be on
a standby alert status.
Fifth: We are calling tonight for an immediate meeting of the Organ of Consultation under the
Organization of American States, to consider this threat to hemispheric security and to invoke articles
6 and 8 of the Rio Treaty in support of all necessary action. The United Nations Charter allows for
regional security arrangements -- and the nations of this hemisphere decided long ago against the
military presence of outside powers. Our other allies around the world have also been alerted.
Sixth: Under the Charter of the United Nations, we are asking tonight that an emergency
meeting of the Security Council be convoked without delay to take action against this latest Soviet
threat to world peace. Our resolution will call for the prompt dismantling and withdrawal of all
offensive weapons in Cuba, under the supervision of U.N. observers, before the quarantine can be
lifted.
Seventh and finally: I call upon Chairman Khrushchev to halt and eliminate this clandestine,
reckless, and provocative threat to world peace and to stable relations between our two nations. I call
upon him further to abandon this course of world domination, and to join in an historic effort to end
the perilous arms race and to transform the history of man. He has an opportunity now to move the
world back from the abyss of destruction -- by returning to his government's own words that it had no
need to station missiles outside its own territory, and withdrawing these weapons from Cuba -- by
refraining from any action which will widen or deepen the present crisis -- and then by participating
in a search for peaceful and permanent solutions. ...
My fellow citizens: let no one doubt that this is a difficult and dangerous effort on which we have set
out. No one can foresee precisely what course it will take or what costs or casualties will be incurred.
Many months in which both our patience and our will will be tested -- months in which many threats
and denunciations will keep us aware of our dangers. But the greatest danger of all would be to do
nothing. ...

Our goal is not the victory of might, but the vindication of right -- not peace at the expense of
freedom, but both peace and freedom, here in this hemisphere, and we hope, around the world. God
willing, that goal will be achieved.

110537258.review:
[b]November 25th, 2021[/b]

"I guess now that we've come full circle, I should get you Volume 1 for the complete set, right?"

Again, I cannot verify that this was exactly what was said, but rather, an approximation. Another friend of mine that watched me read through Volumes 2, 3, and 4 was eagerly waiting in anticipation for my read-through of Volume 1, so he said something along these lines. A different friend had picked up the demo for this game, and I watched him go through this time (albeit only for a little bit, as I played through Volume 1 a bit later).

I was ready for a well deserved break following the rare strain of cringe that was Volume 4. Of course, that break didn't last very long. I was ready to get back into this series once again, but this time I took a little detour before getting back into the Visual Novels. I had discovered that there was not one, but MULTIPLE anime adaptations, the most prominent of which was by Funimation and not some rinky-dink backwater studio. I realized now that what I was dealing with was way bigger than I had initially thought, and was not just some niche indie project that had a small following. This series has sold 5 MILLION copies across 6 games, which blew my initial estimates out of the fucking water.

I watched the first few episodes of the Funimation anime (I eventually did finish it), and my expectations for how much I could cringe at a piece of media were proverbially flattened by an imaginary steamroller disguising itself as anime (I don't really care too much about anime as a genre one way or the other, but I can now see why some call it a 'mistake'). I knew I needed some more preparation before I could face this series again, so I decided to go with something more "tame" and watched the OVA.

However, when I watched the OVA, I noticed that the beginning was very similar to the demo of Volume 1 that my friend had played just days prior. I had now mistakenly obtained most of the knowledge I would've received from Volume 1 by watching an OVA that was one-fifth as long. The problem with this is that now I essentially had no reason to sit through Volume 1, making my experience with this game a particularly boring one.

But before I go into my actual thoughts on Volume 1 as a game, let's string off into yet another aspect of the series that spans more than just the volume in question. Now that I have exhausted the "gameplay", music, and main characters, lets talk about something more juicy that relates to the knowledge that this specific volume gifts you; (*cue fanfare*) the ethics of catgirls! 

After my experience with Volume 2, I needed to know a few things about this universe, and most key among them were "What are catgirls anyway? Have they always been here? Were they engineered somehow? What sort of genetic makeup are we looking at here? Do humans reproduce with cat-people?"

I'm happy to report that finally, after 3 games and zero answers, Volume 1 has finally given me what I was looking for. (I know I could've started at the beginning and found this out a lot sooner, but don't forget that I wasn't originally expecting to play through the entire series)

What I am less happy to report, however, is what the answer actually is. I can sum it up for you in 4 words, taken from the actual game (yes, I did open it again for this review in order to check).

"genetically modified humanoid cats"

At first, genetically modifying cats sounds pretty bad, in my opinion. However, consider the alternative: "genetically modified catlike humans" instantly becomes way worse than modified cats, because that would involve some form of human genetic experimentation, possibly on live subjects, which is certainly not something one should be thinking of while one of the results of these experiments is loudly asking the main character about menstrual pads in public. However, this means that cat-people were [b]created[/b] to be human-like, but beneath humanity as a sub-class of citizen, which is a tragic tale when put in that context.

But now, there comes a new dilemma: what if instead of animal experimentation they instead decided to trace the origin story to cat-people that evolved naturally? Well that opens a new can of worms in the game's universe, since if you remember my volume 2 review, I discussed that the society is set up very similar to a slave society, with catgirls legally unable to do anything independently (a situation that is relevant in Volume 1, surprisingly). So now, the human race essentially has enslaved parts of themselves and cast one race on top of another as the "owners" while independence of the lower caste is illegal, and I don't think I need to explain why that's bad.

That leaves us between a rock and a hard place in how to approach the origins of catgirls. Either they were created in a lab with animal experimentation with the expressed purpose of creating a new pet with human features (often to used to fulfill some kind of sexual fantasy), stripping them of rights that would ordinarily be granted to humans (and since it is revealed that catgirls were typically homeless strays until recently, neglected by the very experiment that brought them into existence), [i]OR[/i], there is a forceful enslavement of humans over cat-people, dehumanizing them and restricting their independence until they are little more than common pets. Nekopara has elected to adopt the first option as the canonical origin story, but both of these options are questionable, neither of which, in my opinion, take a clear moral high ground over the other. 

But enough of my silly rant, let's examine the game now, shall we.

As I mentioned earlier, I had seen the OVA before playing Volume 1, so I already knew what was going to happen, and the experience was relatively boring compared to going in without previous knowledge. However, even in isolation of this fact, Volume 1 is easily the weakest of the main Nekopara series (I say 'main' because there is a worse entry with the "Nekopara" name). The story was the least interesting, largely settling into generic misadventures with Chocola and Vanilla, with occasional references to their backstory and strong attachment to Kashou, which largely feel shoehorned in and contrast poorly with the rest of the story. The only part I'd call passable is the ending, when the catgirls commit a felony by leaving the house without bells, and even then it wasn't very good. I largely feel this was done poorly because Chocola and Vanilla are not well written characters in Volume 1. They lack little human characteristics to make them feel real, which I guess was kind of the point in making them cats. However, later games in the series take more and more gradual steps to make the catgirls feel more human, which makes for more interesting stories later down the line. Even Chocola and Vanilla receive some of these characteristics in later entries (and even the anime, to an extent), and that ultimately improves the quality of these characters. Their characters in Volume 1, however, boil down to little more than "I wuv master uwu cuz he took care of me when I was sick :3 and i wanna have sexy time with him~". I wish there was more to it than that, but other than that, their characters are literally no different than an actual cat; acting on their instincts with 0 regard for those around them, a characteristic even a side character catgirl (who came back in volume 2 renamed "Milk") is better at hiding than these two.

I was unimpressed by Volume 1, and had I started here the proper way instead of looping around via later games I'd likely be unmotivated to continue. However, in this game I received answers to many (but not all) of my questions that had been lingering since I started with Volume 2, which I consider both a blessing and a curse thanks to this. My journey is still not over, but the end is in sight.

tl;dr: nya nya catgirl game 1 answers questions but is boring. watch OVA instead. 4/10

108262204.review:
For a starter I cannot describe how much this game cured my crippling depression, the Nekopara Franchise has honestly cured my depression and helped me with suicidal thoughts. My depression was really bad last month as I had finished high school and becoming a shut in neat, my family kicked me out because I had become too "weird" because of my usual hobbies, I tried to explain that the anime body pillow was the only friend I need but they wouldn't listen. After finding somewhere to move in, my room partner recommended that I try the Nekopara franchise, at first I shrugged it off but after awhile my depression got really bad and it was my friends last wish for me to try the game. The opening of the game filled me with joy as I saw 2 cat girl waifus appear on the screen that was pure eye candy. I dropped everything in my life and started sweating on this game and my depression and misery started to finally fade away after 4 years of torture. The visuals in the game are nothing special but that's one of its charms, the art of the cat girls in this game are 100% waifu content and the art style making me feel good inside. The feelings I get when I play are so mixed that it makes me feel alive again, from laughter to tears, the game makes you feel alive and that you are really there. As people say its not about the graphics that make a game good its about the story and the plot, the Nekopara series of games are far by the best story games of all time and the visuals 100% carry the story, The story follows you as Kashou Minaduki "Master" and your two cat girls Chocola And Vanilla, it makes you wish you were the MC (not Minecraft) and makes you dream you had 2 perfect cat girls at your side. 

The best feature of the game is its adjustable jiggle physics, it made the immersion 100 times better and I would consider that feature one of the main reasons my depression is gone today, half way through the story my depression was almost gone and I could be found sitting in my room for hours at a time enjoying this game. The anime waifus in the game make me so happy and really feel like I am loved and at ease. when I put the game on, it brings a smile to my face and really feels me with joy. When I have bad thoughts of my abusive household I always hop on Nekopara and it makes me feel happy again.
Sometimes I find my self playing this game and staring at the "holy scenes" for way to long and I'm happy to say this game has great "holy scenes" the R18+ Patch is defiantly a must buy with the game looking 9999 times better, the patch makes the game actually have character and makes the "epic scenes" 9999 times better to watch. 

When I play this game I whole heartily play for the plot, don't get me wrong most people play for the "swaggy scenes" but for me I 100% play the plot, the best thing in my opinion has to be its funny use of comedy and how its attached to 2 innocent cat girls that just want "Master" to be happy. I know people way criticise me for being a odd one out for playing for the plot but its TRUE! I genuinely play for this games plot.

Now I know many people are going to be reading this review so I'm going to describe the best way of playing this game without anyone else knowing, you need to obviously need to own the game (DUH) and own a high tech trip wire laser that pulls up your pants and closes the game when activated, you should have these materials laying around but one thing that you might need to get is a good wireless mouse so you can click to advance the plot when your a "little" far from your computer, after these materials it should be self explanatory.

I know I might sound like I'm repeating my self but the game is just one of or maybe the #1 story game out there, not many other games can cure someone's depression that has been going on for many years and not many other games can bring a smile to sad mans face but I can 100% confirm this game will just do that but triple your expectations. To be honest if your reading this far into the review I think you have done yourself a favour and should be the type of person to pick up this game.

If your still reading this I think you want to know a little bit more about my mental health before playing Nekopara, to be honest I have really been suffering and when I go outside I feel like I'm being stared at all times and it doesn't help with my anxiety, When I was inside after being outside all day I feel like I cant breathe and when I got to bed my sleep paralysis demon haunts me everyday, but everything changed when I moved out and became more independent, at first when I moved out I was on the "verge" and wanted to die everyday because it got way worse but one day I got recommended a strange game called Nekopara, to be honest I wasn't having it and had zero interest playing that silly game at all but my friend wished i played it one time so i finally gave in and gave it a shot.

As a final note, I know its not just me who has used this game as a way of escaping and curing my depression, The Game is healing for me, therapeutic for sure. I hear this for lots of others too and I think it’s an absolutely beautiful phenomenon. I’ve never been one to keep up on hobbies and see them through. I always give up when I see I'm just wasting my time. I always feel too lazy to get up and do something or my depression takes over. This is not the same. I’m yearning all the time to get back in the game and fix the thing I messed up last session. I’m always wanting to see if I am just good enough to have those 2 as my waifus. I just wanted to say that I am so grateful for this game and I hope it brings you the peace and joy it brings me even as just a starter. I honestly think that this game is the BEST GAME IN THE WORLD!!!!

3/10 (sound track too expensive)

I have never in my life been so thoroughly bored playing a game. Even titles like Crackhead, which I consider a complete waste of time and money, provided more entertainment than this. Visual novel games, such as the one in question, often run the risk of being inherently dull due to their heavy reliance on reading comics. However, many manage to inject excitement through mini-games or meaningful choices, which is sorely lacking here.

For those seeking entertainment, I would suggest turning to the anime adaptation instead. It offers a relatively enjoyable experience, free from the drawbacks and discomfort found within the game. However, I strongly caution against subjecting oneself to the tediousness and unease that accompany playing this title.

99935040.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 31.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: :hillary: minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.
After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

So, in short this is a high quality 4-6 hour erotic Visual Novel for cat lovers. If you have a cat, you'll like this game.

[Noteworthy Stuff]:

-You need to buy an 18+ patch to scene any lewd content.

-There's a total of 3 s*x scenes that play out towards the later hours, all of which you can revisit in a CG Gallery, Scene Gallery, and Video Gallery at the title screen. They're mostly pictures but a few parts in the scenes have *thrusting*. All 3 are fairly long with quite a bit of text and dialogue to go with it.

-Fully voiced (in Japanese) for all characters except you (i read my parts out loud for deeper immersion) [but i read them in english so idk if my catgirls understood me...]

-At the title screen, in 'Extras', there's a CG Gallery, Scene Gallery, Music Gallery, And Video Gallery. They all unlock as you progress.

-There's a slider where you can adjust how bouncy the breasts are. Also, press P at any given time to make them bounce at will. With great power, comes great responsibility... (!!!)

-It's a straight VN, so there's no interaction or dialogue options. It's pretty text heavy and you gotta play a while before you hit the lewd scenes. Think of it like a manga but with jiggle physics ^.^

-There's a Log where you can backtrack to re-read stuff but no 'back' button to rewind scenes like in other VN's. There's also an auto-forward mode with it's own settings (for hands-free play) and a Skip button that only works after you've passed a scene once.

Lastly, I'd strongly recommend getting this on sale because of the length and price. Especially because you're gonna want that 18+ patch that you have to buy on top of buying the game. Then you're gonna wanna buy Vol. 2, which also requires you to buy another 18+ patch. Then Vol. 3 and you get where this is going. So ya. 

Meow on, cat daddies (and mommies) ^.^

95918860.review:
[h1]Introduction[/h1]
[b]Nekopara[/b] is a kinetic visual novel developed by [b]NEKO WORKs[/b] and published by [b]Sekai Project[/b]. There has been a lot of hype about this series since its release in 2014 and I have finally decided to give it a chance to see how it lives up to all the praise. There are a total of four volumes and a prequel in this series so I have chosen to start with the first game that was released, volume 1.

[h1]Story[/h1]
[b]Kashou Minazuki[/b] is the son of a long line of Japanese confection makers. One day, he decides to move out and start his own bakery called [b]La Soleil[/b]. When he arrives at his new location, two large boxes appear and upon opening them, he found two catgirls named [b]Chocola[/b] and [b]Vanilla[/b] packed inside. Originally, they were at [b]Kashou’s[/b] old home and owned by his younger sister [b]Shigure Minaduki[/b]. The two catgirls feel that [b]Kashou[/b] is their true owner and followed him to his new location.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2549208026 
[b]Kashou[/b] tried to send them back but they begged and pleaded until he eventually gave in to their pleas. The two catgirls at hand, who really love their master, will try their best to help run the bakery and will do their very best with varying results.

[h1]Pros and Cons[/h1]
[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
[*]A cute kinetic VN with cute catgirls
[*]Interesting characters that show development throughout the story
[*]Beautiful art style that is very pleasing to look at
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
[*]The story is very bland and lacks excitement
[*]I do have some issues with the characters
[*]Some people may be turned off by some of the sexual storyline aspects
[/list]

[h1]Characters[/h1]
Every catgirl you meet is cute and has a different personality. They learn and grow in the world around them. [b]Chocola[/b] and [b]Vanilla[/b] particularly are new to the outside world so their interactions tend to be very childlike at first. There are a group of characters that you will meet but this volume focuses on [b]Chocola[/b] and [b]Vanilla[/b] so I’ll be covering those two respectively.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2549208475
You follow in the footsteps of [b]Kashou[/b] and we are in his perspective throughout the story. He is easygoing and is willing to lend a hand whenever he can, however, at times he can be a bit dense. Sometimes he is incapable of getting hints and has to be told directly what's on someone's mind.

[b]Chocola[/b] is cheerful, has a dog-like personality, and is very fond of her master [b]Kashou[/b] so much that she wants his attention. At the same time, she is energetic, friendly, and well-loved by those around her. [b]Chocola[/b] has a hard time doing difficult tasks and tends to leap into action without thinking of the consequences.

[b]Vanilla[/b] is the twin sister of [b]Chocola[/b] and is the exact opposite in terms of personality as she is quiet and calm. She can be smart but does prefer to do things on her own, however, she does remain kind-hearted and well-liked.

Out of the two, [b]Vanilla[/b] is my personal favorite due to her quiet nature and I would personally like to hang around her more than her hyper sister.

[h1]Problems with the story[/h1]
The story is good but unfortunately, it falls short in many areas that prevent it from being anything more than average. There are no events that would serve to add excitement to the story instead I found myself more just waiting for the spicy scenes to happen as the primary focus. We do get to see [b]Kashou’s[/b] bakery gain gradual success, but it is not much else there.

Next, I have issues with two characters. Now I should point out that I do not hate these two in any shape or form but I still have problems with them. 

[b]Chocola[/b] is the first character that I found issues with. While I didn't hate her character, I found her to be a big attention magnet in general. This is subjective of course, but I did not like how more attention was put on her compared to her twin sister [b]Vanilla[/b]. I understand that [b]Vanilla[/b] is meant to be the quiet one, but characters like that typically get their very own big moment and story segment. Unfortunately, this never happens so she becomes more of a background character being completely taken over by [b]Chocola[/b]. I feel some more time would have been nice on the other cat girl, especially when they did such a good job making her equally as interesting.

Then, there is [b]Kashou[/b], he falls flat in terms of character development. He does not really do much outside his focus on the bakery. There was a moment where he did talk about leaving his family due to some issues, however, this was not touched upon further in the story. I don’t know if this is tackled in the other volumes but it’s left untouched in this volume leaving us with a boring main protagonist.

The final issue I have is that some of the sexual story elements may be a turnoff for some people. If you are looking for a cute kind of VN, then [b]Nekopara[/b] does offer that, however, it will be drowned out with the spicy scenes later on.

[h1]Artstyle, Performance, and Soundtrack[/h1]
The art style is something that I was really impressed with. There are some really beautiful scenes that you will be able to see throughout the game and each is very detailed. [b]Nekopara[/b] should run fine on any computer due to this being mostly pictures, music, and text. I came across no issues while I was playing. I tested the game on an NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1060 3GB, AMD Ryzen 5 1500X Quad-Core Processor 3.50, with16 GB of RAM. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2549208605
The soundtrack is an area that could have been shown some more love. There were no tracks that were bad or distracting, but also none that stood out or were memorable. The music choices simply fit the requirement of having background music while you play through the story.

There is an 18+ patch that is available for 11.49 CDN through Steam. This adds adult content that further shows how the relationship between Kashou and the girls develops. The patch includes three segments of H-scenes that are animated and fully voiced that are very well done. Personally I believe these scenes help complete the experience and should absolutely be picked up if you enjoy adult content in visual novels. 

I also recommend going into the options settings and maxing out the chest jiggle physics. After that, press the "P" button on your keyboard during the regular dialogue scenes as you are in for a cute treat. This function will work with or without the patch.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
If you like are looking to play a visual novel with cute catgirls, then [b]Nekopara[/b] will most definitely meet your needs in this area. It has a nice charm with standout art in both the character and background scenes. As this is a kinetic visual novel, there aren't any dialogue choices that will change the routes or endings of the game, so be sure to temper your expectations as you are getting more of a story with cute cat girls more than something that will feel like a game.

I recommend [b]Nekopara[/b] to anyone who loves catgirls as I felt that even looking at the shortcomings developer [b]NEKO WORKs[/b] absolutely knows how to do catgirls. ;3

I also recommend getting the 18+ patch, you get the full experience of the story, and don’t forget to max the chest jiggle.

94766550.review:
Visuals - 9/10
Let's start with the positives. The animation was way better than I was expecting. The characters are drawn in 2D but they move like 3D models, and it gives the game a unique visual style that looks really nice. The backgrounds are vibrant and detailed, and the character designs are really good.

Music - 7/10
I was actually impressed. It was pretty basic, but overall sounded pleasant and fit the visuals well.

Characters - 4/10
The characters are pretty uninteresting. While they're likable for the most part, it seems like the authors took one, maybe two character traits and based their entire personality around just that. Instead of any real character development, we get the cheerful one, the tsundere one, the horny one, etc.

Story - 2/10
The story really didn't do anything for me. For the first couple chapters seemed like a vague coming of age story, but by the last few it completely departed from that and tried to be a love story. The problem is, when you don't really care about any of the characters, why should you care who they date? The climax was really weak and seemed like a last minute addition to wrap things up. The plot overall just felt insignificant.

Sex Appeal - 3/10
For very clearly being intended as a hentai game, the fact that you have to buy the sex scenes separately is just insulting. Gameplay - 0/10
The gameplay is clicking to progress the story. I get that it's a visual novel, but this game is just begging for any kind of player interaction. Even just giving the player options for how they interact with the characters would have done wonders. You made all these characters, let me interact with them! Instead we get to listen to Mr. Wonderbread talk about how he really cares about his family or some shit. Insulting.

Overall - 3/10
On the surface Nekopara looks nice, but it's essentially just a really boring book with a nice coat of paint. I would, however, really like to see the artists behind this work on a project that has actual merit outside of novelty. Can you imagine if Danganronpa looked this good?

94034356.review:
I am running out of what I can write about with regards to Nekopara. This series isn't that interested in "innovation" or new ideas, so everything I've written about the previous three games applies to this one; Nekopara Vol. 4 is likewise a lighthearted comedy visual novel about catgirls and their "master" with a healthy dose of fan service.

In fact, Volume 4's very opening scene is, on the PC, a sex scene. That has been "censored" for the Nintendo Switch release, but as you play through it, you just know that in the adult version what you'll see in that scene is very different. I've written about this a couple of times in the past, but I actually think that Nekopara benefits from the less explicit imagery. Without it, the art and sense of humour combine to give players something silly and charming, in a naive kind of way. The various catgirls are all adorable, bubbly dolts in their own way, and the overall impression that the narrative leaves is light and irreverent. That texture of the entire experience changes when explicit sex is part of the mix. It's well-drawn art, as anime erotica goes. It's just at odds with the rest of the narrative, and so my feeling is that the Switch version isn't any the lesser without that element.

The narrative itself is good fun. Despite all the success that he's enjoyed from events of the previous three games in setting up and managing a respected patisserie, protagonist Kashou is still without his father's approval, and after being on the receiving end of an aggressive lecture and put-down when Kashou returns home for his mother's birthday (some husband, Kashou's dad), he decides to head on over to France to further master his craft. There, in addition to chasing his dreams, he'll meet a new catgirl, learn more about himself and the harem of catgirls that he has following him everywhere.

Like most harem stories, there are clunky elements to Nekopara's writing. Because each and every character needs to have equal treatment and their own little moment to shine, there are times where the pacing grinds to a halt, as the narrative takes the opportunity to give every single character a moment to share their thoughts. Because Nekopara is also slice-of-life stuff, the meandering nature of the story means that it will often feel like nothing at all is happening. It's fun writing, and of course the point of the game is all about making you laugh along with these catgirls rather than enjoy some kind of meaningful plot, but it's also undeniable that there's something vapid to the Nekopara series, and the expanded cast by now contributes to making this one feel like the most meaningless of them all.

It is a gorgeous game for what it is though. The character models are highly detailed and beautiful, and perhaps this is just my perception talking here, but there does seem to be more animation in this one than in games past. Characters move around, angle themselves and bounce up and down (jiggle physics and all) as the situation demands. There were a couple of moments where there was so much movement going on that I wasn't sure whether there was a slight graphics engine bug going on, but on balance it's a great effect, and a big step above what most visual novels offer. The key CGs are also all masterpieces of fanservice art.

As with previous chapters in Nekopara, there aren't any branching paths to deal with, no dialogue trees, and no minigames or other such distractions. It's a purely linear narrative. The one example of interactivity is the ability to pull up a virtual hand at any point. In principle, you're meant to use it to pat the heads of the catgirls, and they'll positively purr with delight when you do that. Of course, you can use it to play with their chests instead. Which will cause their faces to go a bit red and demure, but of course they all seem to like that you're doing that just fine too. This interactivity does nothing for the game but for the demographic that the series is developed for, it is a great addition, you'd expect.

Nekopara is what it is. As a highly fanservicey, comedy-themed visual novel, it's hugely entertaining and delivers on all of its promises. The fan service is excellent thanks to the superb art, and the humour is there - it's silly, but you won't be able to help yourself but giggle along with it. If the pornographic scenes that are available on the PC version of the game are of interest to you, then the Switch port's going to feel like it's missing something. It's still more than fanservicey enough, however, and I actually think the narrative and thematic elements are strengthed in the restraint. Couple that with the portability of the Switch form factor, and I think this is the best way to go for Nekopara Vol. 4.

This VN game is as good as they say. Too bad the girls in this volume is not my cup tea. With an expected tearjerker of a backstory I say you can either play this with or without the adult patch.

Visuals, voice acting, story... 7 out of 10 for this volume since like I said earlier, the available girls are not to my personal liking (size wise).

Also, the most common flaw in these VN games is the pacing which made me struggle to stay awake since when things get slow, it REALLY gets slow. Skipping it sometimes made me miss bits of the story details and it didn't feel right so I had to play this when I had extra time to spare.
